instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one port stuck at 5v
threads.message: Hello. I got a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in that had some minor liquid damage and corrosion around the backlight output caps and the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips. When I plugged in the app meter, it would not even turn on for either port. Found short on <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL> so I replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and the short was gone. Now when I connect the charger to the port for <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, it goes to 20v 0.60a, but the port for <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> stays at 5v 0.01a and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0v when using this port only. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.3v when connected to the other port so not sure what is happening. I have replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> 3 times now with the same result each time so <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is not the issue. It seems like <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is being shorted to ground whenever I used the usb port for <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, but it measures .329 in diode mode. Any idea what could cause this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one port stuck at 5v
threads.message:
Use the logic; you cannot have short on a rail where you get voltage from other port!

Non-working port doesn't open input MOSFET probably.
Replace that MOSFET, but check its series coil first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one port stuck at 5v
threads.message: Sorry which MOSFET should I replace? There was some corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q3350</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q3360</TRANSISTOR>, and <TRANSISTOR>Q3351</TRANSISTOR>. I replaced all 3 but no change.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one port stuck at 5v
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> is the corresponding MOSFET of <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>.
Be sure first it gets 5V on the input; check fuse and coil.
You can bypass it IN-OUT, only for test...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one port stuck at 5v
threads.message: Yea that was it. I changed <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> and now I got 20v on both ports and the board boots. Thanks for the help.
